text.p: *The June Australian three-year bond struck a new high for 1997 of 93.67 in after hours trading, continuing the advance since last Friday's official interest rate cut.
*April retail trade due at 11.30 a.m. (0130 GMT).
*U.S. Treasuries firm on foreign demand, 5-year note sale.
The June Australian three-year bond futures contract struck a new high for 1997 of 93.67 in after hours trading, continuing the advance since last Friday's official interest rate cut.
The contract ended SYCOM at this peak compared with Thursday's firm 93.61 pit close and after finally overcoming the 93.60 level which was seen immediately after the rate cut.

The contract is now in the thick of a 93.65/93.68 resistance zone and a break could see a test of 93.72 en route to the 93.80 peak seen briefly last December, and highest level seen since February 1994.
However, "Strength past 93.68, if seen, should be sold," said Peter Pontikis, technical analyst at Westpac.

He said the contract is already in an overbought zone, the three/10-year bond futures spread is near major resistance at 125 basis points and a potential retracement in U.S. Treasuries should all hold back the three-year contract.
Bill futures also firmed in SYCOM with the September position touching a contract high of 94.57, equating to a cash rate of 5.43 percent and just below 5.5 percent official rates.
Economists are reluctant to discount another easing, and speculation was fuelled by comments from Prime Minister Howard.
Speaking at a mining industry dinner Prime Minister John Howard said that while Australia had seen significant reductions in interest rates, real interest rates were still too high.

The market keenly awaits April retail trade at 11.30 a.m. (0130 GMT) for an indication of current demand. Forecasts centre on a 0.5 percent rise after the 0.3 percent fall in March, according to a Reuters survey of economists.
Also due are April motor registrations, which are seen being flat, and first quarter balance of payments, forecast to show a A$4.8 billion deficit.
